course_name: GEOG101 - Human Geographies: People, Space and Change (0.50)
major_name: Bachelor of Applied Science Degree Requirements
topics: E-mail: bdoberst@uwaterloo.ca

An introduction to human geography through key subfields of the discipline, examining population change, the rise of cities, our relationship to nature, social inequalities, economic forms, cultural difference and environmental change at the local and global scale.
So-called “food geography” is then explored, followed by an examination of the geographic basis of patterns of urbanization, and an exploration of global economic activity.

The course concludes with a short unit on hazards geography, analysis of global development patterns and processes, and an assessment of human impacts on and sustainability in terrestrial and marine environments.
For Winter 2025, course content will be delivered through a combination of in-class lectures and self-viewed readings and videos.
Compare and contrast Human Geography theory with real-world expressions of Human Geography
Construct solutions which apply Human Geography concepts and skills to real-world sustainability problems

course_name: GEOG202 - Geography of the Global Economy (0.50)
major_name: Bachelor of Applied Science Degree Requirements
topics: An introduction to globalization of the world economy through an examination of its causes, patterns, and consequences in a variety of geographic contexts.
GEOG202 is an introduction to the global economy and the discipline of economic geography.
We then explore several contexts that have given rise to the global economic system and consider the evolving spatial distribution of its industrial sectors.
We conclude with a discussion of the present and future implications of economic globalization for both developed and less developed nations.
Describe the current state of the global economy, including knowledge of key economic indicators and their strengths and limitations
Define the central comments necessary for understanding contemporary global economic issues.
Critically analyze economic issues from a geographic point of view, emphasizing spatial differences and the importance of national, political, social and cultural context
Evaluate the importance of geography, space and difference in the global economy

9 March 12  Environment: Does global climate change everything?

course_name: GEOG203 - Environment and Development in a Global Perspective (0.50)
major_name: Bachelor of Applied Science Degree Requirements
topics: Environment and Development in a Global Perspective Fall 2024
Farah El-shayeb (felshaye@uwaterloo.ca)
Examines the interface between human development and the environment in a global context.
In this course, we will examine some of the most pressing environmental and development issues facing our world today, as well as international development efforts to address these.
These efforts include interventions to help individuals and communities adapt to change through climate resilient agriculture, biodiversity, and clean energy transition.

Several international development practitioners working in these areas will visit our class as guest speakers to share insights about some of the challenges and opportunities they face in implementing their work.
Understand the historical evolution of international development and its linkages to globalization and economic growth.
Translate international development ideas into practical strategies via a grant writing exercise.
Enhance your professional development and communication skills through interactions with international development practitioners.
Global trade and development
Guest speakers: Tiffanie Rainville and Kerry Max, Global Affairs Canada
Adaptation and development
FAO 2017

major_name: Bachelor of Applied Science Degree Requirements
topics: Climate Change Fundamentals Winter 2025
Climate change is one of the most profound environmental and social issues affecting communities, nations and individuals.
Climate change is a pervasive and challenging phenomenon that can be viewed through a multitude of lenses.

A scientific lens, for instance, reveals altered ecosystems and climatic tipping points while the lens of ethics raises the question of the right to develop and influence the well-being of others while doing so.

By carefully laying the scientific foundations, we will explore creative, positive, nuanced visions of the future that are rooted in scientific understanding of earth systems but also capture (or at least begins a conversation about) core human values, such as equity, compassion, innovation, and connection.
Demonstrate understanding of key elements of the climate system, and how these elements are being altered by the human emission of greenhouse gases.
Carefully consider the impacts of climate change on both human and natural systems.
Articulate the difference between climate change adaptation and mitigation, and understand a portfolio of actions that communities can take to respond to climate change.
Understand the key issues at play in international climate change negotiations, as well as recent Canadian policy proposals.
Investigate futures that are fundamentally sustainable, low-carbon, and resilient to climate change impacts.
Week 2: Introduction to the climate system, discussion activity, quiz

course_name: GEOG306 - Human Dimensions of Natural Hazards (0.50)
major_name: Bachelor of Applied Science Degree Requirements
topics: Human Dimensions of Natural Hazards - GEOG 306 Winter 2025
E. Mohammadi
E-mail:            elham.mohammadi@uwaterloo.ca

The physical nature of a wide range of geophysical and biophysical hazards will be explored, paying particular attention to the ways in which hazards become dangerous to humans, and the pathways by which humans can either increase or decrease their vulnerability in the face of natural hazards.
Natural hazards and associated disasters are, in part, a product of inappropriate human modifications or management of the natural landscape.
Throughout the course, case studies and examples drawn from countries and regions around the world will be used to clarify conceptual and methodological issues.
Appreciate the physical processes associated with various natural hazards, with a focus on geophysical, meteorological, and hydrological hazards.
Appreciate the key components of preparing for disasters.
Apply knowledge to compare hazards theory with real-world case studies.

course_name: GEOG307 - Societal Adaptation to Climate Change (0.50)
major_name: Bachelor of Applied Science Degree Requirements
topics: Societal Adaptation to Climate Change Winter 2025

Recognizing that dangerous climate change cannot be avoided through greenhouse gas emissions reductions alone, adaptation to climate change has emerged as a central component of global climate policy.

An in depth understanding of the diverse impacts of climate change on communities, economic sectors and society will provide a foundation for examining adaptation strategies to build resilience to accelerated climate change.
Examples will draw from multiple sectors in both developed and developing world contexts, with an emphasis on solutions and the limits to adaptation.
Understand the types of response options human societies have in light of present and future climate change
Be aware of the differential impacts and vulnerabilities introduced by climate change, and how these interact with development outcomes.
Critically examine the ways in which we communicate climate change
Articulate the way climate change-related impacts, adaptation and vulnerability affect various sectors and locations
Adaptation in the energy sector
Guest speaker: Dr. Kitinya Kirina

major_name: Bachelor of Applied Science Degree Requirements
topics: Email peter.crank@uwaterloo.ca

This course provides an overview of the key concepts related to climate services (i.e., useful, timely, and robust information about climatic trends that can support decision-making) and the development of the United Nations' Global Framework for Climate Services.
The value of climate-informed decision-making across diverse sectors of the economy are examined, both for climate variability and extremes today and in an era of accelerating climate change.

The scientific and practical challenges of utilizing climate information for decision-making in government policy, community planning, business operations, and international development, as well as the technical standards and professional ethics associated with providing climate services, are examined.
Students gain practical experience in the development and application of climate services through climate data assembly and interpretation.
Articulate what climate models are, and how they are formulated and tuned.
Use a hierarchy of models helps to answer critical problems in climate science.
Apply climate models and data to a diverse range of sectors and problems.
Skills learned will be applicable to those pursuing graduate school in a physical science discipline as well as other advanced climate research topics, including:
The development of the Global Framework for Climate Services
Climate variability assessment
Climate-informed decision-making across societal sectors
Professional ethics in providing climate services
Global Framework for Climate Services & WG1 CH12)
Global Framework for Climate Services

Station data & homogenization
IPCC WG3 Ch. 2.2-2.3
Groups identified for TikTok-style videos

Students will need to respond to and discussion 5 posts through the term regarding the climate science and/or the sectors of climate services presented in class and via guest lectures.

Students will be asked to used generative AI to explore how large language models are interpreting the varying opinions on climate change in the Canadian context and compare to the scientific evidence of climate change.

To demonstrate knowledge of the climate science and data, students will be required to work in teams of 3-5 to develop Instagram Reels/TikToks which depict the current knowledge of climate science, climate models, and climate change.
This creative content should be directed toward the general public and/or peers to educate others on the current knowledge of this field.
To demonstrate knowledge of the application of climate services, students will need to create an infographic which describes the importance of climate data in a sector & region of the world.
Students will work in teams of 2-3 undergraduate students with one graduate student to explore the climate services used in a particular sector of the economy/society.

course_name: INDEV200 - The Political Economy of Development (0.50)
major_name: Bachelor of Applied Science Degree Requirements
topics: The Political Economy of Development Fall 2024
E-mail: imorales@uwaterloo.ca
This course develops students' understanding of how the complex interplay of international economic and political economy factors influence development initiatives and outcomes.
How is it that you came to be a political economist?
Well, if you believe in ‘development’ it logically follows that you believe in change: changing from an undesirable condition to an improved condition is commonly thought of as ‘development’.
Effecting change in such a situation requires a combination of social acceptance and economic capacity.

Your approach may emphasize one or the other, but without the buy-in of key social actors your plan will fail no matter how well-equipped you are financially, technologically, or in terms of the resource base; conversely, without the ability to marshal key resources, all the buy-in in the world cannot lead to successful implementation of your plan.
In effect, you are theorizing about the relationship between and among your key variables: you are constructing a theory of political economy!
Or perhaps you feel that without a fundamental alteration in the political structure of a society or with the current unequal allocation of resources, there can be no broad-based positive change.
What’s a development practitioner to do?!
In this course you will be introduced to political economy’s (i) key concepts; and (ii) different theoretical approaches in historical and contemporary context.

We do this not just to give you an overall description of the world of international development, but to assist you in understanding why things are the way they are, why different actors have tried to change the situation in particular ways, and what perhaps still remains to be done.
(a) a solid understanding of political economy;
(b) a good general knowledge of the main issues in the political economy of international development;
(c) a good general knowledge of the key actors, forces and factors in international development;
(f) an improved skill set for informing better policy making, be it for a state, a civil society organization or a private sector company.
Introductory Overview: Models and Tools of Political Economy

topics: E-mail: pnayak@uwaterloo.ca
Individuals, communities and nations in all regions of the world are experiencing the effects of climate and human induced changes in their physical and social environments.

The highest and the most direct impact of these changes are seen in the case of commons (e.g., fisheries, shellfish beds, coastal spaces, lagoons, mangroves, range lands, forests, groundwater, freshwater systems, irrigation systems, urban spaces, etc.) upon which humans depend for their social, cultural and economic needs.
In a similar sense we all, as humans, are linked to some form of commons in our daily lives - we either impact the commons or get impacted by it or experience both.

Within the community, rights to the resource are unlikely to be either exclusive or transferable; they are often rights of equal access and use, and held as a collective under well-defined institutional arrangements and rule system.
In other words, in a commons situation, the exclusion or the control of access of potential users is difficult and each user is capable of subtracting from the welfare of all other users.
Both these characteristics of commons add to their complexity, generate new contestations and help explain various critical perspectives and dynamic processes associated with the commons.

Important to note here that commons are influenced by the prevalent social, cultural, economic, ecological and political history and traditions of the specific contexts within which they are situated and impacts of several internal and external drivers across multiple scales.
This makes the commons dynamic over time, consistent with the literature that suggests that commons institutions may go through processes of development and decline.

At the end of this course, students will have (a) a firm grasp of the meaning and complexity of commons and its various components through studying theory, concepts, scholars and practice; (b) a critical understanding of interdisciplinary / multidisciplinary approaches to the study of commons; (c) a good grasp of the main issues involved in the debates around commons; (d) an analytical knowledge of the key drivers and actors influencing the making or breaking of the commons; (e) a solid understanding of the links between commons and its role in sustainable development; (f) a capacity to critically analyze challenges facing the commons in different parts of the world and the nature of struggles, strategies adopted by communities, governments and civil society to deal with it; (g) a solid perspective on how to sustain the commons and carry them into the future through appropriate governance arrangements.
The basic pedagogy of the course will include an interesting mix of conceptual and empirical information delivered through evidence-based learning methods and structured lectures.

First half of the class time will be devoted to dealing with the conceptual aspects of the topic mainly through a mix of interactive lecture and facilitated seminar and the remaining half of the class time will be used to discuss an empirical case study or guest speakers that can offer practical examples to help explain selected commons topics more succinctly.
Class seminars and discussions will also revolve around a set of required and recommended readings wherein students will be encouraged to participate in a meaningful way.

Office hours: Tues & Thurs, 4:00-4:45pm
INTEG 221:

This course examines social aspects of knowledge, including ways that characteristics of individual knowers and their communities affect the acquisition, interpretation, production, and transfer of knowledge.
The course features significant input from researchers in the humanities and social sciences in the form of guest lectures.

course_name: INTEG240 - Bullshit, Bias, and Bad Arguments (0.50)
major_name: Bachelor of Applied Science Degree Requirements
topics: I'm Dr. John McLevey.
I'm an Associate Professor in the Department of Knowledge Integration (Faculty of Environment).
I'm also a member of Sociology & Legal Studies, and Geography & Environmental Management.
Email: john.mclevey@uwaterloo.ca

The course will cover a broad range of issues from a social scientific perspective, including comparisons of different types of deceptive information; the role that cognitive biases and social networks play in shaping our perceptions of truth and reality; the importance of data rights, privacy, and governance models for social media platforms and other digital communications; misrepresentations of science; and how influence campaigns undermine political deliberation and democratic institutions.
This course will provide students with knowledge and fundamental skills that are important for countering bullshit, biases, and bad arguments.
Explain the role that our social networks play in shaping our individual and collective beliefs and behaviours
Describe the social mechanisms that enable true and false beliefs to spread, and how we can better understand these mechanisms using quasi-experimental designs and computational simulations
Explain what philosophers and sociologists of science mean when they refer to 'truth' and 'false beliefs'

Explain how the science of complex contagions and social scientific research on identity and political polarization offers insights into possible solutions to the problems of misinformation and disinformation
However, Knowledge Integration students will note many (intentional) connections to content introduced in other first and second year KI courses.

Concepts and theories introduced in this course will also help prepare students for other KI courses, including "Research Methods and Design,"  "Computational Social Science," and a wide variety of other electives.

topics: Students will gain an understanding of how organizations identify the needs of potential consumers and create and deliver value to these consumers through the marketing process.

Certain concepts from business and economics including market responsiveness, decision-making process, willingness to purchase, product differentiation, and advertising will be incorporated into the development of a strategic marketing plan.

In addition to teaching central concepts and models from both marketing and economic theory, students will be placed in a forum where they can apply these concepts in a 'real world' marketing situation.
Describe the basic principles of marketing, the marketing process, and its economic foundation.
Demonstrate how marketing discovers and satisfies consumer needs and wants.
Analyze internal and external factors contributing to the current state of organizations.
Demonstrate the use of marketing tools including branding, positioning, and segmentation.
Integrate the marketing mix elements into a strategic marketing plan.

course_name: MUSIC253 - Cathedral and Court: Music to 1600 (0.50)
major_name: Bachelor of Applied Science Degree Requirements
topics: Email: ksteiner@uwaterloo.ca

A study of major developments in western music during the Middle Ages and Renaissance, including Gregorian chant, mass, secular songs, instrumental music, and other musical genres that flourished under courtly and church patronage from the early Christian church to 1600.

We will consider 1) major changes in the sounds of music 2) major developments in the ways music was recorded 3) major changes in the roles music played in societies 4) topics related to issues today that help us compare and contrast medieval and Renaissance society with contemporary Canada.
To learn the basic theory, history and culture of music of the medieval and Renaissance eras in the West.
To apply theoretical, historical and cultural knowledge of early music to music listening and analysis.

course_name: NE109 - Societal and Environmental Impacts of Nanotechnology (0.50)
major_name: Bachelor of Applied Science Degree Requirements
topics: Societal and Environmental Impacts of Nanotechnology Fall 2024
Howard Siu

Nanotechnology in society; health and environmental sustainability; introduction to environmental life cycle assessments; engineering ethics, policies, and regulations; Canadian legal system, tort, and intellectual property; examples of nanotechnology innovation and commercialization.
An introduction to the field of nanotechnology and its ability to impact society and affect sustainability.
How utilization of nanotechnology has simultaneously improved societal standards of living and introduced new ethical, health, and environmental concerns will be examined.

Topics covered will include: the history of changing perceptions of and attention devoted to developments in nanotechnology; special health and environmental concerns associated with nanomaterials; the development and means of implementation of regulations to deal with the use of nanomaterials; ethical issues associated with nanotechnology and its applications.
Relevant case studies will be presented and discussed.
Analyze case study problems from regulatory, ethical, and legal perspectives
Be familiar with the concepts of intellectual property and, more specifically, the patenting process
Impact on the Environment: Forms of man-made pollution, their effects upon the environment, and standard methods of waste-water treatment.
Applications of nanotechnology in medicine will also be examined.

Regulating Nanotechnology:  An examination of the purpose of regulations, including the concepts of life-cycle analyses, environmental management systems, risk assessment, cost-benefit analyses, and the precautionary principle.
Science & Technology and Politics: A quick introduction on how government policies can influence the development of science and technology.
Ethics: Types of ethics, ethics pertaining specifically to professional engineering and science, as illustrated through a number of case studies.
Tort Law: Canadian legal system, criteria for a tort, potential nanotechnology torts in the near future, and examination of several case studies.
Intellectual Property: Types of intellectual property, application for patents in Canada, potential concerns facing patent applications for nano-enabled inventions.
Business Structure: Pros and cons of sole ownership, partnership, incorporation.

course_name: PLAN100 - Urbanization Today: Introduction to Cities and Regions (0.50)
major_name: Bachelor of Applied Science Degree Requirements
topics: Urbanization Today: Introduction to Cities and Regions Fall 2024
B. Doucet

Dr. Brian Doucet firmly believes that academic knowledge should be shared with wider audiences to enhance not only scholarly debates, but also political, policy, planning and public discussions about cities and communities.
He is a frequent commentator in the media and has experience and expertise speaking with a wide range of audiences about many important urban topics.
Dr Doucet’s first full-length documentary film Thinking Beyond the Market: a film about genuinely affordable housing, will be released in fall 2024.

His interest in cities and transportation began at an early age; his childhood home was within earshot of the Yonge subway line and as a child, he spent many hours watching trains from the bridge over the tracks!
He is particularly interested in the relationship between new transit lines and processes of gentrification and displacement.
His first book Why Detroit Matters (2017, Policy Press) examined counternarratives and inspiring visions in Detroit.
He was previously a competitive curler and represented the Netherlands at the European Curling Championships in 2008, 2010 and 2011.
This course considers the history of urbanization, models of urban and regional development, and ideals of good urban form in Canadian and global contexts.
Students will develop a critical perspective on the historical and contemporary relationships between processes of urbanization and broader societal trends and structures.
Introduction
We will explore different models of urban development, the role that shifting economic and social forces have played on the growth and development of cities, and different eras of urbanization.
Rather than only describing these changes, this course will introduce a critical perspective on the impacts of urbanization and urban change on marginalized groups.
The course will be taught through a combination of thematic lectures and case studies of challenges facing particular cities.

A key component of this course is to encourage and challenge students to look differently at the world around them in order to examine planning’s role in what we see visible (and invisible) in our cities.

Part One, The Growth and Development of Cities (weeks 1-6) explores different ideas and practices about how cities developed over time, as well as introducing different parts of the city (downtowns, inner cities, suburbs, mid-sized cities etc).
Learning Modes and Expectations:
The lectures will be given by Dr Brian Doucet and will introduce and explain key concepts, issues and examples.
The tutorials will be divided into smaller groups of around 25-30 students and held in the days following each lecture.
We understand that most of you are first-year students entering a new phase of your studies and that university education comes with very different expectation than other places of learning.
One of the main goals of this course is to develop critical thinking and observation skills in order to start your journey towards ‘thinking like a planner.’

As a result, we are more interested in your own thoughts, ideas and knowledge about a topic and how these can all grow throughout the course, rather than what you can find and produce through a generative AI software program.

course_name: PLAN341 - Ecology and Conservation for Planning (0.50)
major_name: Bachelor of Applied Science Degree Requirements
topics: Ecology and Conservation for Planning Winter 2025
This course provides students with a critical understanding of the relationship between human development and natural environments.
Students will develop an understanding of core ecological principles and how these can be taken up in plans and policies to promote nature conservation in urban and rural environments.

The course will include examples of how planners mitigate the environmental impacts of development of land, allotment of open space and parks, and conservation of sensitive areas and species in both urban and rural contexts.
